turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Monsieur Félix -- ?

turns.speaker: FÉLIX
turns.text: I was expecting you. You are American too, of course.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: FÉLIX
turns.text: The man who bought them last week was American. I did not see him but I heard. I knew you would come.

turns.speaker: FÉLIX
turns.text: Have you ever, in your entire life, seen anything so beautiful?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I'm -- I'm sorry -- I don't know anything about stamps.

turns.speaker: FÉLIX
turns.text: I know them as one knows his own face, even though I have never seen them. This yellow one -- a Swedish four shilling -- called 'De Gula Fyraskillingen' -- issued in 1854.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: How much is it worth?

turns.speaker: FÉLIX
turns.text: The money is unimportant.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I'm afraid it is important.

turns.speaker: FÉLIX
turns.text: In your money, perhaps $65,000.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Do you mind if I sit down?  What about the blue one?

turns.speaker: FÉLIX
turns.text: It is called 'The Hawaiian Blue' and there are only seven left. In 1894 the owner of one was murdered by a rival collector who was obsessed to own it.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: What's its value today?

turns.speaker: FÉLIX
turns.text: In human life? In greed? In suffering?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: In money.

turns.speaker: FÉLIX
turns.text: Forty-five thousand.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Do you have anything to eat?  And the orange one -- what about the orange one?

turns.speaker: FÉLIX
turns.text: A two-penny Mauritius -- issued in 1856. Not so rare as the others -- $30,000 perhaps.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: And the last one?

turns.speaker: FÉLIX
turns.text: The best for the last -- le chef- d'oeuvre de la collection. The masterpiece. It is the most valuable stamp in the world. It is called 'The Gazette Guyanne.' It was printed by hand on colored paper in 1852 and marked with the initials of the printer.  Today it has a value of $100,000.  Eh, bien -- I am not a thief. I knew there was some mistake. Take them.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: You gave the boy quite a lot of stamps in return, Monsieur Félix -- are they for sale now?

turns.speaker: FÉLIX
turns.text: Let me see. There are 350 European, 200 Asian, 175 American, 100 African and twelve Princess Grace commemorative -- which comes to nine francs fifty.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Here's ten.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Please keep it.

turns.speaker: FÉLIX
turns.text: I am a tradesman, Madame, not a doorman. And don't forget these.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I'm -- I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: FÉLIX
turns.text: No. For a few minutes they were mine -- that is enough.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: That was a dumb move, Herman -- a dumb move.

turns.speaker: TEX
turns.text: And then some. If you'd only told us you was goin' to her room we could've kept 'em busy --

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: I suggest you get about your business -- nothing soothes Herman like success.

turns.speaker: TEX
turns.text: That's right -- it's like ticklin' a alligator's belly.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: What for? If it's not here, why bother him?

turns.speaker: TEX
turns.text: And if it is?

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: Why bother him?

turns.speaker: TEX
turns.text: You sure nuthin's missin'?

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: No. The police have kindly provided us with a list.

turns.speaker: TEX
turns.text: There sure ain't nothin' here worth no quarter of a million.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: Not unless we're blind.

turns.speaker: TEX
turns.text: You think that mebbe we're fishin' the wrong stream?

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: Meaning what?

turns.speaker: TEX
turns.text: You don't s'pose one o' us has it, like the man said -- I mean, that'd be pretty distasteful -- us bein' vet'rans o' the same war 'n' all.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: You know I'd tell you if I had it.

turns.speaker: TEX
turns.text: Nachurly. Jus' like I'd tell you.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: Nachurly. And that goes for Herman, too.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: What do you mean, no?

turns.speaker: TEX
turns.text: The kid said --

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: Mrs. Lampert --

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: Didn't Charles tell you, Mrs. Lampert?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Tell me what?

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: It doesn't belong to you, Mrs. Lampert -- you do know that, don't you?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I don't know anything.

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: Mrs. Lampert, any morning now you could wake up dead.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Leave me alone -- !

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: Dead, Mrs. Lampert -- like last week's news -- like Charles, Mrs. Lampert --

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Stop it!

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: I'm afraid that will have to wait, Mrs. Lampert.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: But his mother --

turns.speaker: GIDEON
turns.text: She isn't going to be anybody's mother unless you answer some questions.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: GRANDPIERRE
turns.text: I am Inspector Edouard Grandpierre of the Police Judiciaire. Would you be so kind as to come with me, please?

turns.speaker: GRANDPIERRE
turns.text: You loved him?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I'm very cold.

turns.speaker: GRANDPIERRE
turns.text: We discovered your husband's body lying next to the tracks of the Paris- Bourdeaux railroad line. He was dressed only in his pajamas. Do you know of any reason why he might have wished to leave France?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Leave?

turns.speaker: GRANDPIERRE
turns.text: Your husband possessed a ticket of passage on the 'Maranguape.' It sailed from Bordeaux for Maracaibo this morning at seven.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I'm very confused.

turns.speaker: GRANDPIERRE
turns.text: He was American?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Swiss.

turns.speaker: GRANDPIERRE
turns.text: Oh. Swiss. His profession?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: He didn't have one.

turns.speaker: GRANDPIERRE
turns.text: He was a wealthy man?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I don't know. I suppose so.

turns.speaker: GRANDPIERRE
turns.text: About how wealthy would you say?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: GRANDPIERRE
turns.text: Where did he keep his money?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: GRANDPIERRE
turns.text: Besides yourself, who is his nearest relation?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: GRANDPIERRE
turns.text: C'est absurde, Madame. To-tale-ment absurde!

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I know.  I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: GRANDPIERRE
turns.text: It is all right.

turns.speaker: GRANDPIERRE
turns.text: Is it all right?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I wish you wouldn't.

turns.speaker: GRANDPIERRE
turns.text: One wallet containing four thousand francs -- one agenda --  -- his last notation was made yesterday -- Thursday --  "Five p.m. -- Jardin des Champs- Elysées"  Why there?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I don't know. Perhaps he met somebody.

turns.speaker: GRANDPIERRE
turns.text: Obviously.  One ticket of passage to South America -- one letter, stamped but unsealed, addressed to you --

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: A letter? May I see it?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: "My dear Regina: I hope you are enjoying your holiday. Megeve can be so lovely this time of year. The days pass very slowly and I hope to see you soon. As always, Charles. P.S. Your dentist called yesterday. Your appointment has been changed."  Not very much, is it?

turns.speaker: GRANDPIERRE
turns.text: We took the liberty of calling your dentist -- we thought, perhaps, we would learn something.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Did you?

turns.speaker: GRANDPIERRE
turns.text: Yes. Your appointment has been changed.  One key to your apartment -- one comb -- one fountain pen --  one toothbrush -- one tin of tooth powder  -- that is all.

turns.speaker: GRANDPIERRE
turns.text: If you will sign this list you may take the things with you.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Is that all? Can I go now?

turns.speaker: GRANDPIERRE
turns.text: One more question. Is this your husband's passport?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Of course it is.

turns.speaker: GRANDPIERRE
turns.text: And this?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I don't understand.

turns.speaker: GRANDPIERRE
turns.text: And this? And this?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I was, too.

turns.speaker: GRANDPIERRE
turns.text: In Mr. Dyle's room?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: No -- in my room.

turns.speaker: GRANDPIERRE
turns.text: It stands to reason you are telling the truth -- for why would you invent such a ridiculous story?

turns.speaker: JEAN-LOUIS
turns.text: Oh, la.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Don't tell me you didn't know it was loaded.  Sylvie!

turns.speaker: JEAN-LOUIS
turns.text: Yes, of course -- but if you went back and wrote me a letter --

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: -- you could have the stamps. I'll get you some here, okay?

turns.speaker: JEAN-LOUIS
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: JEAN-LOUIS
turns.text: Oh, la! If I find the treasure, will I win a prize?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: What should we give him?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Come on, now -- if you wanted to hide something, where would you put it?

turns.speaker: JEAN-LOUIS
turns.text: I know. I would bury it in the garden.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Swell -- only this man doesn't have a garden.

turns.speaker: JEAN-LOUIS
turns.text: Oh.  Neither do I.  Voilà!

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Voilà what?

turns.speaker: JEAN-LOUIS
turns.text: Up there! I would put it up there!

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I hope I don't find any little hairy things living up here -- wait! There is something! If I can just -- yes, I'm getting it -- a case of some sort -- it's heavy.

turns.speaker: JEAN-LOUIS
turns.text: I found it! I found it!

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: If you think you're getting credit for this, you're crazy.

turns.speaker: JEAN-LOUIS
turns.text: We won! We won!

turns.speaker: JEAN-LOUIS
turns.text: Up there! It is up there!

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: No, Jean-Louis.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Jean-Louis -- thank heavens! Do you have -- !  What's that?

turns.speaker: JEAN-LOUIS
turns.text: A man traded with me -- all those for only four.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Oh no! What man, Jean-Louis --  where?

turns.speaker: JEAN-LOUIS
turns.text: But he is gone.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I don't blame him. Jean-Louis -- do you know where this Monsieur Félix lives?

turns.speaker: JEAN-LOUIS
turns.text: No -- but I will ask.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Oh, forgive me.  Is this yours?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: It's hers. Where'd you find him, robbing a bank?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: He was throwing snowballs at Baron Rothschild.  We don't know each other, do we?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Why, do you think we're going to?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I don't know -- how would I know?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I'm afraid I already know a great many people. Until one of them dies I couldn't possibly meet anyone else.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Yes, of course. But you will let me know if anyone goes on the critical list

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Quitter.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: How's that?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: You give up awfully easy, don't you?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Clever fellow -- almost missed me.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I'm afraid you're blocking my view.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Sorry. Which view would you like?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: The one you're blocking. This is the last chance I have -- I'm flying back to Paris this afternoon. What's your name?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Peter Joshua.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I'm Regina Lampert.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Is there a Mr. Lampert?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Good for you.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: No, it isn't. I'm getting a divorce.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Please, not on my account.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: No, you see, I don't really love him.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Well, you're honest, anyway.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Yes, I am -- I'm compulsive about it -- dishonesty infuriates me. Like when you go into a drugstore.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I'm not sure I --

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Well, you go in and you ask for some toothpaste -- the small size -- and the man brings you the large size. You tell him you wanted the small size but he says the large size is the small size. I always thought the large size was the largest size, but he says that the family size, the economy size and the giant size are all larger than the large size -- that the large size is the smallest size there is.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Oh. I guess.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Is there a Mrs. Joshua?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Yes, but we're divorced.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: That wasn't a proposal -- I was just curious.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Is your husband with you?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Oh, Charles is hardly ever with me. First it was separate rooms -- now we're trying it with cities. What do people call you -- Pete?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Mr. Joshua.  Well, I've enjoyed talking with you.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Now you're angry.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: No, I'm not -- I've got some packing to do. I'm also going back to Paris today.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Oh. Well, wasn't it Shakespeare who said: "When strangers do meet they should erelong see one another again"?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Shakespeare never said that.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: How do you know?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: It's terrible -- you just made it up.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Well, the idea's right, anyway. Are you going to call me?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Are you in the book?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Charles is.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Is there only one Charles Lampert?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I phoned but nobody answered. I wanted to tell you how sorry I am -- and to find out if there was anything I could do.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: How did you find out?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: It's in all the afternoon papers. I'm very sorry.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I rang the bell but I don't think it's working.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Yes it is -- I heard it this morning.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Where did everything go?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Charles sold it all -- at auction.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Do you know what you're going to do?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Try and get my old job back at UNESCO, I suppose.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Doing what?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I'm a simultaneous translator -- like Sylvie, only she's English to French -- I'm French to English. That's what I did before I married Charles. The police probably think I killed him.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Instant divorce you mean?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Something like that. But I'm sorry it ended like this -- tossed off a train like a sack of third-class mail.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Come on. You can't stay here.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I don't know where to go.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: We'll find you a hotel.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Not too expensive -- I'm not a lady of leisure anymore.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Something modest but clean -- and near enough to UNESCO so you can take a cab when it rains -- okay?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Hallo, Peter.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You telephoned me to meet you. I've been standing on the corner back there -- waiting for you.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I'm sorry -- I heard the children laughing.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What's going on?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Don't you understand French?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I'm still having trouble with English.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: The man and the woman are married --

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Of course? I thought he was dead.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: He's only pretending, to teach her a lesson -- only --  only he is dead, Peter -- I saw him -- he's not pretending. Somebody threw him off a train. What am I going to do?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Right there, between your eyes -- see? Worry lines. You're much too young and too pretty to have anything like that. How about making me vice- president in charge of cheering you up?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Starting tonight?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What was all that?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Fun and games. Evidently we're the floorshow.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You mean you and me?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: No, everyone. Come on -- avanti, avanti!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: En garde.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Lay on, MacDuff.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What are you doing in here?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Having a nervous breakdown.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You haven't said a word since we left the club -- what happened back there?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I -- I'm not sure if I'm supposed to tell you or not.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I don't think I follow you.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: He said if I told anybody it could prove fatal for them as well as me.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Who said?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: That's what I'm not supposed to say.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Stop this nonsense! If you're in some sort of trouble I want to know about it.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Stop bullying me. Everybody's bullying me.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I wasn't --

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Yes, you were -- you called it nonsense. Being murdered in cold blood isn't nonsense. Wait until it happens to you sometime.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You said this afternoon that your husband was mixed up in something.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: How do you shave in there?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What was it?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: What was what?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What your husband was mixed up in.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Look, I know it's asking you to stretch your imagination, but can't you pretend for a moment that I'm a woman and that you're a --

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Don't you know I could already be arrested for transporting a minor above the first floor?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: We're here.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: On the street where you live.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: How about once more around the park?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Him: 'Do you mind if I come in for a nightcap, Reggie?' Her: 'Well -- it is awfully late.' Him: 'Just one, all right?' Her: 'Promise you'll behave yourself.' Him: 'Sorry, baby, I never make promises I can't keep.'

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: How would you like a spanking?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: How would you like a punch in the nose? Stop treating me like a child.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Then stop acting like one. If you're really in some kind of trouble, I'd like to hear about it. Otherwise, it's late, I'm tired and I'm going home to bed.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Do you know what's wrong with you?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Nothing. Good night.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Good night.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Peter -- are you all right?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I think I sprained my pride.  Where'd he go?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Out of the window, I guess -- I didn't see him.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Lock the door and the window -- and don't let anyone in except me. I'll be back in a minute.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Be careful, Peter.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You took the words right out of my mouth.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: There was no trace of him. All right, Reggie -- suppose you tell me what this is all about.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: There are three men -- he's one of them -- they think I have something that belongs to them.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: A quarter of a million dollars.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Go on.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: That's all.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: No, it isn't -- where's the money?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I don't know.  Those men killed Charles to get it. But he must not have had it with him on the train.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: So they think he left it with you.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: But he didn't! I've looked everywhere --  And if I don't find it --  Those men going to kill me.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: No, they won't -- I won't let them.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Please help me, Peter -- you're the only one I can trust.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Of course I'll help -- I told you I would, didn't I? Come on now --

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I'm so hungry I could faint.  I've -- I've gotten your suit all wet.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: That's all right -- it's a drip-dry.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Peter, you've got to promise me something. Promise you'll never lie the way Charles did. Why do people have to tell lies?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Usually it's because they want something -- and they're afraid the truth won't get it for them.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Do you tell lies?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Who is it?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: The man you had the fight with.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Yes -- that's right.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What is it, Reggie -- what's he saying?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What'd he say?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: He -- he said if I didn't give the money, he'll kill me.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I wouldn't take that too seriously.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I believe what he said.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: They're only trying to scare you, that's all.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: How do you know what they're doing?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I don't -- but as long as they think you have the money, or know where it is, or have it without knowing where it is, or don't even know you have it --

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You mustn't let what he said bother you. It was only words.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Words can hurt very much.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Go to sleep -- I'll see you in the morning.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Don't put yourself out.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Hey -- I'm on your side. Remember that.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Yes, I'll remember. Good night.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Good night.

turns.speaker: TEX
turns.text: Miz Lampert, ma'am...

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: TEX
turns.text: Charlie had no call to handling it this-a-way. He sure didn't. No siree.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I don't understa--

turns.speaker: TEX
turns.text: Howdy, Miz Lampert.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Wha -- what do you want?

turns.speaker: TEX
turns.text: You know what I want, Miz Lampert...

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: No -- no, I'm don't.

turns.speaker: TEX
turns.text: Come on now -- sure you do. An' you'd better give it to me, Miz Lampert -- cuz I ain't foolin'. No sireebob!

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Stop that!

turns.speaker: TEX
turns.text: Don't make too much noise, Miz Lampert --

turns.speaker: TEX
turns.text: It belongs to me, Miz Lampert -- an' if you don't give it to me your life ain't gonna be worth the paper it's printed on. You savvy what I'm sayin', Miz Lampert?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Please stop -- please!

turns.speaker: TEX
turns.text: You think on it real careful-like, Miz Lampert -- y'hear?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Can you give me one good reason why I should?

turns.speaker: TEX
turns.text: Yes, ma'am. A little one -- 'bout seven or eight years old. Th' little tyke keeps callin' you his Aunt Reggie -- ain't that cute?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Isn't there something constructive he can do -- like start an avalanche?

turns.speaker: SYLVIE
turns.text: Va jouer, mon ange.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Sylvie -- I'm getting a divorce.

turns.speaker: SYLVIE
turns.text: Ça alors! From Charles?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: He's the only husband I've got. I tried to make it work, I really have -- but --

turns.speaker: SYLVIE
turns.text: But what?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I don't know how to explain it. I'm just too miserable.

turns.speaker: SYLVIE
turns.text: But why do you want a divorce?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Because I don't love him.

turns.speaker: SYLVIE
turns.text: But that is no reason to get a divorce!

turns.speaker: SYLVIE
turns.text: With a rich husband and this year's clothes you will not find it difficult to make some new friends.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I admit I moved to Paris because I was tired of American Provincial,

turns.speaker: SYLVIE
turns.text: He knows everything.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Don't you want me to stay?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: It's not exactly what I'd call a large turn-out.

turns.speaker: SYLVIE
turns.text: Didn't Charles have any friends?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Don't ask me -- I'm only the widow.  If Charles had died in bed we wouldn't even have him.

turns.speaker: SYLVIE
turns.text: At least he knows how to behave at funerals.

turns.speaker: SYLVIE
turns.text: Have you no idea who could have done it?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Until two days ago all I really knew about Charles was his name -- now it turns out I didn't even know that.

turns.speaker: SYLVIE
turns.text: Do you know him?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I've never seen him before.

turns.speaker: SYLVIE
turns.text: He must have known Charles pretty well.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: How can you tell?

turns.speaker: SYLVIE
turns.text: He's allergic to him.

turns.speaker: SYLVIE
turns.text: Who is it from?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: The American Embassy.

turns.speaker: SYLVIE
turns.text: What is it about?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I don't know.  But if this is a sample of American diplomacy I'm buying a fallout shelter.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I hope Jean-Louis understands about last night -- it's just not safe for him to be around me right now.

turns.speaker: SYLVIE
turns.text: Don't be silly -- he would not do anything. He is not yet old enough to be interested in girls. He says collecting stamps is much more satisfying to a man of his age.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Hold it -- Italy just finished. They're recognizing Great Britain.

turns.speaker: SYLVIE
turns.text: Oh la vache!

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Sylvie -- ? What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: SYLVIE
turns.text: Hello, Reggie -- I am waiting for Jean-Louis.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: What's he up to?

turns.speaker: SYLVIE
turns.text: He was so excited -- when he got the stamps you gave him this morning. He said he had never seen any like them.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I'm glad. But what's all this?

turns.speaker: SYLVIE
turns.text: The stamp market, of course -- it is here every Thursday afternoon. This is where Jean-Louis trades his --

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Good Lord! The stamps! Where is he? Sylvie -- we've got to find him!

turns.speaker: SYLVIE
turns.text: What's the matter, chérie?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Those stamps -- they're worth a fortune!

turns.speaker: SYLVIE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: A fortune! Hurry -- we've got to find him!

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I don't see him.

turns.speaker: SYLVIE
turns.text: We will separate -- you look over there.

turns.speaker: SCOBIE
turns.text: We took all the chances. The money belongs to us, not him!

turns.speaker: TEX
turns.text: Don't be un-neighborly-like, Herman -- don't forget he done us a little ol' favor.

turns.speaker: SCOBIE
turns.text: Yeah? What's that?

turns.speaker: TEX
turns.text: He took care of Charlie for us.

turns.speaker: TEX
turns.text: Shoot no, not after all these years.

turns.speaker: SCOBIE
turns.text: Then he gets it out of your share, not mine! Not mine!

turns.speaker: TEX
turns.text: Howdy, Miz Lampert.

turns.speaker: SCOBIE
turns.text: Who invited you?

turns.speaker: TEX
turns.text: This ain't no game, Miz Lampert.

turns.speaker: SCOBIE
turns.text: We want that money -- now!

turns.speaker: ANNETTE
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: KILLER
turns.text: I'm Lisa Sherman. Dylan's aunt. He asked me to come talk to you.

turns.speaker: ANNETTE
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: KILLER
turns.text: He feels terrible about those things he said to you in school.

turns.speaker: ANNETTE
turns.text: He should. Four guys hit on me today, and not because they find me intellectually stimulating.

turns.speaker: KILLER
turns.text: I think I know how to restore your reputation.

turns.speaker: ANNETTE
turns.text: You do?

turns.speaker: KILLER
turns.text: Can I come in? I'll need to use the phone.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Yeah. Chris BERRINGER WAS PARKED OUTSIDE THE WINDOW.

turns.speaker: CINDY
turns.text: I wonder why it's so important to know if they fucked?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: What I don't understand is why they asked Marliston if Rod was a virgin. They could have asked you Cindy.

turns.speaker: CINDY
turns.text: I never fucked Rod.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Exactly. Then he must be a virgin.

turns.speaker: CINDY
turns.text: If I'm so all-used-up Ben, why do you try to hook me up non-stop?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: As fucking if.

turns.speaker: CINDY
turns.text: I think it's funny.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Me too. I'm going to start telling people that I saw her drop to her knees and latch on to his unit vector.

turns.speaker: CINDY
turns.text: I'm not fucking you. Not for all your CDS.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: You want me to die? I thought you and I were tight.

turns.speaker: CINDY
turns.text: ARE YOU THE KILLER BEN?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: WOULD that impress you? IS that what it takes to impress the empress?

turns.speaker: CINDY
turns.text: Your mind is just twisted enough. I believe you'd do all this just to get a dip or two.

turns.speaker: CINDY
turns.text: I get all your CDs.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Not my imports.

turns.speaker: CINDY
turns.text: Ok not your imports. All your other CDS and your K2 snowboard.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: That's an awful lot for ten minutes of beasting?

turns.speaker: CINDY
turns.text: Don't flatter yourself. You'll be lucky to last ten seconds with me Ben.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: One more time.

turns.speaker: CINDY
turns.text: I get the imports.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Ok!

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: You aren't planning to tell these kids that 'virgin' was tattooed into both Stacy and Rod, are you?

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: But I am going to have to question all of their past boyfriends and girlfriends.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Fine, just don't mention the carving This is going to be a tough enough day as it is.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Hi Jody.

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: I just wanted to check that you were okay?

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: Why'd you send for Lenny Marliston?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: The kids adore him. They confide in him. His patchouli reeking rear might know if Stacy and Rod were really virgins. Why didn't you ask Jody that?

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: She's my daughter, Tom.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: So?

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: So you just don't point blank ask your teenage daughter about sex.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Why not? You worried you might find out how much she actually knows?

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: If I'd gone public with this yesterday Annette Michaels might be alive today.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Oh GOD Brent, is there anything you don't feel guilty about?

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: is there anything you do?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Focus on the present. You always want to change the past. Let's figure out what you are going to tell the parents today, not what you should told them yesterday.

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: I'm going to tell them everything I know. I'm calling a town meeting for eight p.m.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: You tell these people someone is out there killing virgins and we're going to have a goddamn fuckfest on our hands.

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: Better than a pile of dead teenagers.

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: IT'S LISA SHERMAN. But she still looks like we're eighteen.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: That's impossible.

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: I swear to God. It's her. She told Jody she was Kenny's 'AUNT LISA'. I'm getting this sickly feeling...

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Calm down Brent.

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: It's almost ten o'clock.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: Daddy you scared me!

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: You're grounded Friday night!

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: What? I WAS AT SANDY'S I JUST LOST TRACK OF TIME.

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: Your curfew is 9:30 and you know it, little miss.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: It won't happen again.

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: You said that two weeks ago.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: Dad ! Most of my friends can stay out until 11 on school nights and 1 on weekends!

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: They're not all the sheriff's daughter. Goodnight.

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: Hi honey.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: Hi Daddy. Hi Mr. Sisler.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: I'm fine. I've just never had someone my age die before. It's so weird.

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: How well did you know Stacy and Rod?

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: I've been in the same class with Stacy for years but we weren't tight or anything.

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: Had either of them broken up with someone recently? Hurt someone?

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: No. Those two were together before Kenny and I started hanging out and that's over, what, God a year now.

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: I want you to head right home after school.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: I will. Is that all?

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: Hi honey.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: What's wrong?

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: I have a question to ask you. A personal question.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: Well, I assume you let him kiss you?

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: Well yeah. Of course. Everyone kisses.

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: I'm not criticizing. _ Did you two get any further?

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: A little.

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: How much further?

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: Daddy! I DON'T THINK THIS IS ANY OF YOUR BUSINESS!

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: I wouldn't ask if I didn't have to.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: Not much further.

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: You never went, uh, all the way?

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: Ok.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: Daddy, are you upset that I'm still a virgin?!

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: No honey.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: You are upset.

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: I'm not.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: I thought you'd be pleased.

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: I am. I'm so very proud of you. Go back to sleep.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: It was a she.

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: Are you sure?

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: She said she was Kenny's aunt Lisa.
